content.description:
This is a fun route that has some interesting moves down low and then fun jug hauling up high. After climbing easily to the first clip, moving past a thin-hands crack (placing a cam along the way if you like), and clipping the next bolt, things get interesting. Make crux moves past the next few bolts to a good ledge. Some bolts down low cannot be easily seen from the starting ledge but show up when you need them. After gaining a ledge with a no-hands rest, continue more easily to the top on big holds.

(The route name was obtained from the guidebook to the park by Dave Bingham.)
content.protection: Bolts. I forgot to make an exact count but I'd say a dozen draws plus something for the anchor should be sufficient. A thin-hands size piece can be placed between the first two bolts; there's currently a very stuck cam in that area that can be clipped. Bolted rappel anchor at the top. We used a 70m rope and had plenty left after lowering. I think a 60m rope should work.
content.location: The route starts about 20 feet to the right of Pre-Emptive Strike. Scramble up to the start of that route and continue a bit to the right on the same platform until you see the next set of bolts.

climbs.name: Pre-Emptive Strike
climbs.fa: Mike Anderson (solo), D Hernandez D Cruz, and P Heeken

content.description: Climbing is on excellent patina granite, pulling on significant jugs/edges. Start with a difficult side pull/balance move off the deck and move up the patina face. 10 feet of easy 5.10 and then cruise the rest of the route at 5.7. There is a second set of anchors at approx 50 feet up so the route can be broken into two pitches if desired. (and also rappelled in two pitches). We used a 70 meter rope and did one  pitch lead and rappel.
content.protection: Route consists of bolts but pro can be placed if desired (not necessary) to chain anchors on the face near the top of the pillar.
content.location: The route goes up the north face. Starting from the highest point on the north side, scramble around behind a large detached flake of rock moving west along the bottom of the north side of Bracksiecks Pillar until you come to a small tree growing out of the rock. This will be just west of the major weakness that ascends the north face.

content.description: Climb the first pitch of Crack Class.  When you get to the top of the first pitch build your anchor low, because you wont want it in your way as you head straight up the steep finger crack.  Crank through the first 20-30' and enjoy the ride to the top.  One of the best routes in the area.
content.protection: 3x purple to yellow metolius with a few more yellow.  single to #2 BD.
content.location: find Crack Class and youll see it

content.description: Bolts and Small Gear lead up to Eye-Full Tower's anchors.
content.protection: 3 or 4 bolts small to medium nuts and cams. Chain anchor.
content.location: North side of bracksieks Pillar, left of Eye-Full Tower start.

content.description:
Furthest left route on Bracksiek's Pillar's East face. Climb the 5.8 approach pitch as for B Bro and Lil Buckaroo but from the chains below B Bro continue left of the trough on a bolt line. Pull a fun mantle move to gradually steepening slab climbing. Clip the rap chains mid pitch at a patina face and keep climbing onto another slab and to the top of the feature. Fun varied climbing that is protected well.

We descended with 3 rappels with a 70m rope.
content.location: Furthest left route on Bracksiek's Pillar's east face. Shares the same first pitch as B Bro (Chocolate Rib) and L'il Buckaroo

content.description:
This is the attractive finger crack in a left-facing corner above the first pitch of

Alpinista Sista

.  Unfortunately, the climbing is not as enjoyable as it looks because the crack is abrasive and the surrounding face is grainy.  From the spacious ledge atop the first pitch of

Alpinista

, face climb to the crack then persevere until several feet below a tree.  Step out left and join the last few moves of

Alpinista

to the chains, or if a real glutton for punishment, lunge for the tree then ascend the mossy, rotten, wide crack above.
content.protection:
Set of nuts and cams to hand-size.  Microcams useful.  Lower/rap from

Alpinsta Sista's

chains to the starting ledge.
content.location:
Second pitch variation to

Alpinista Sista

.

content.description: One Pitch, Bolts to a Chain Anchor.
content.location: East side. First bolts you come to walking up from the SE. Rap Route one 60m rope.

content.description: Climb up and clip the first two bolts on the face to the right (2nd pitch of Eye-Full Tower).  Use of a long runner on the second bolt will help with any rope drag.  Traverse to the right across and up the lower angle ramp in the middle of the face to the corner to the right and continue to the belay anchor (hanging) just below the summit rim.
content.protection: Bolt protected.  Belay anchor is at an uncomfortable non-stance.  Recommend carefully lowering the leader back to the 1st pitch belay anchor (first pitch of Eye-Full Tower).
content.location: Variation starting at the first pitch belay station of Eye-Full Tower.  Rappel the route taking care to watch the rope ends and ensure you can get back to the first pitch anchor (a guided lower or rappel works fine).

content.description: Climb up the huge plates on steep jugs finishing at the belay anchor atop the first pitch.  100'.  Ascend to the right, then up face to corner to top of spire.  60'.  Rappel route.
content.protection: Bolted.  Fixed anchor belay stations.  Some protection can be placed between the upper bolts on the first pitch as there's some runout.  Medium size cams would suffice.
content.location: Located on the north side of Bracksieck's Pillar.  Follow trail to upper east side, then cut through notch to nice staging area.  The route is just past the notch before the tree.  Rappel route.

content.description: Super route! Start with a curving finger crack (10a) then jam up a nice splitter from fingers to large hands to a ledge. Belay here.  Next, Chimney up behind the unprotected giant leaning block,  Once on top of the block traverse climbers left to where the block ends, locate hand crack on opposite wall, sack up and step across from the block to the main wall ( a fall here would be bad) and jam up the fun 5.8 hand crack.  Build anchor on top and rap down " Pre-Emptive Strike" on the North West Side.
content.protection: Doubles from .5 to #3 Camalot, set of nuts and TCU's
content.location: South West side of Bracksieck's Pillar.  The starting curved crack is easily seen once on the SW side.  Rap the NW side from chain anchors.

climbs.name: Cool Crack
climbs.fa: Brad Schilling, FFA C.Wayment, M. Anderson

content.description: This route ends with the beautiful slightly overhanging thumbstack and thin hands crack.  Crack Class shares the less than vertical top.  The first pitch is full value with an akward thin slot .  Building an anchor as close to the crack on the second pitch will really help out.
content.protection: standard rack for the first pitch up to #3 camalots.  Heavy on.75 and 1 camalots.
content.location: It might take a little while to decide on the base.  Don't climb up as if for crack class, but rather continue onto the SW side looking for the flaring crack.

content.description: Starts on a slabby rib with some interesting moves. Second pitch is amazing, fun, slightly overhanging, patina surfing goodness.
content.protection: Bolts and chain anchors, a number 4 camalot could go into the undercling flake at the start of the 2nd pitch but the bolt wasnt to bad to get to.
content.location: East side of the pillar, just up from Apinista Sista.

content.description:
By the end of this route I was calling it the Chocolate Rib.  That should be its name.

This is in the Bingham Guide to the area.

First pitch melow 5.8.

Second pitch is tricky and steeper...cruxy.

Third pitches is Full Value 5.9.  Maybe 5.9+.  Exciting trad climbing leads to bolted slabby arete rib feature sweet patina.  Rap from chains.

Hardest 5.9 on Bracksieks Pillar.

We had two 60 meter ropes for descending.  We rapped back to top of Lil Buckaroo in one rap.
content.protection:
Mostly bolted, except the first 40 ft of pitch 3 5.8.  One each to 2 inches will definitely suffice and prob be too much.  I dont really remember exactly.

All Bolted Belays. Cant remember but one each to 2 inch will definitely suffice.
content.location: First pitch is Lil Buckaroo Route which is 5.8.  Find in Dave Bingham's Castle Rocks A Climbers Guide.  Mano Izquierda 10.a climbs a bolt line to the left.  Aim for the Chocolate Rib.

content.description: The new book says 3 pitches but i think the second set of anchors is intended for the decent and can easily be done in 2.  Great route with varied climbing and a fun mantle move.  A little grainy but with a little more traffic should clean up nicely.
content.protection: The book says bolts and a little gear but i diddnt find gear to be necissary at all.  Chain anchors.
